{{cpp/title|terminate_handler}}
{{cpp/error/navbar}}
{{ddcl|header=exception|
typedef void ( *terminate_handler )();
}}

{{tt|std::terminate_handler}} is the function pointer type (pointer to function that takes no arguments and returns {{c/core|void}}), which is installed and queried by the functions {{lc|std::set_terminate}} and {{lc|std::get_terminate}} and called by {{lc|std::terminate}}.

A {{tt|std::terminate_handler}} shall terminate execution of the program without returning to the caller, otherwise the behavior is undefined.

The C++ implementation provides a default {{tt|std::terminate_handler}} function, which calls {{lc|std::abort()}}. If the null pointer value is installed (by means of {{lc|std::set_terminate}}), the implementation may restore the default handler instead.
